newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Rouble eases after funds set aside for T-bills.
newsitem.headline: Rouble eases after funds set aside for T-bills.

text.p: The rouble eased on Wednesday as banks gathered sufficient funds for today's Treasury bill auctions, after rising briefly on dollar selling by a foreign bank, dealers said.
Today the central bank is auctioning 7.5 trillion roubles of six-month paper and four trillion roubles of three-month bills.
"The period when foreigners were selling dollars (in the previous days) for today's auctions is over and the market is settling down as usual. Trading is rather calm," one dealer said.
Aljba Alliance Bank chief dealer Dmitry Slobodnik said the rouble had risen earlier as a foreign bank was selling dollars but the rouble's upward trend turned out to be short.
"Everybody expects roubles to come back to the market (after the T-bill auctions) as usual so the dollar is going up again," he said.

Roubles for today settlement were quoted at 5,307-10 per dollar compared with an early 5,300-03 and 5,297-300 late on Tuesday. Tomorrow roubles eased to 5,316-18 per dollar from yesterday's late 5,300-03.
The central bank said it had set 5,285/5,325 as its bid and offer rates against the dollar on Wednesday.
Overnight rouble credits yielded 30-45 percent compared with Tuesday's late 50-70 percent.

As usual the rouble-dollar market was unaffected by renewed worries about the health of President Boris Yeltsin, which earlier pushed up the Swiss franc, traditionally a safe haven on global currency markets.
Yeltsin aides have repeatedly said the president is resting outside Moscow and is not ill.
"The market is already immune to the rumours of this kind," one dealer said.
Slobodnik said: "It is foreigners who are usually scared by such things but what this market reacts to are concrete things such as central bank instructions, reserve requirements and so on."
